title.narrative: Food Security and Health for East Africa

description.narrative: Strategic aims and objectives of "Food Security and Health for East Africa"Our strategic aim through "Food Security and Health for East Africa" is to build interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary capacity within and between St Andrews-based research excellence and key partners in the UK, Malawi, Tanzania, Uganda and Kenya to co-develop innovative ways to tackle the connected challenges of food security and health. The challenges have been identified with partners and through local involvement spanning more than 10 years of extensive collaboration. The overarching objectives of "Food Security and Health for East Africa" are: (i) to produce new climate resilient and disease resistant potato varieties tailored to potato production systems; (ii) to reduce human Schistosomiasis through innovative biocontrol using prawns (Macrobrachium rosenbergii) to predate the snail intermediate parasite hosts and, at the same time, produce food; (iii) to increase diagnostic accuracy of TB and COPD to improve antibiotic stewardship and treatment outcomes.

This "Food Security and Health for East Africa" GCRF GRTA proposal focuses on breaking the current vicious circle of poor sustenance and poor human health by tackling food security and health challenges as a single highly connected developmental issue. The context of our proposal is the interrelationship between people and their environments seen through the lenses of food security and health, with the specific objectives of: (i) improving the availability of staple food by producing new climate resilient and disease resistant potato varieties that can be grown in East Africa; (ii) reducing the incidence of human Schistosomiasis by using prawns (Macrobrachium Rosenbergii) to disrupt the infection cycle; and (iii) increasing diagnostic accuracy of tuberculosis (TB) and Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Diseases including improving antibiotic stewardship in the treatment of these diseases. Nutrition boosts immunity making nourished people less susceptible to infection, and if infected, they have better treatment outcomes.
